Issues.Title: Scoped style inheritance inconvenient
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
To reproduce the issue which let to my suggestion please follow [the example](https://codesandbox.io/s/jjl952o545).

A particular inherited style in the example is founded to not work: 
```css
.master header nav .btn svg {
  fill: #7f7f7f;
}
```
which is the color fill of the vector.

So in order to solve the issue I had to use what you suggest as deep selector 
`.btn >>> svg` 

However  that creates great inconvenience for example in my project the master element has a lot of children so I have to go through hundred of style lines to ensure if every selector is applied and doesn't need deep selecting.
Indeed the issue has workarounds  and it's debatable of is it a matter of scoped styling but I believe it is the case scoped through inheritance much like the `props` attribute works for the js API. Sometimes how an element looks and is styled really depends to the component it belongs to.
Pardon me if there's something I overlooked and that isn't an actual issue. 

### What does the proposed API look like?
What catches my attention about scoped styling is it goes down to the following structure:
`<div data-v-783f90ce=""><header data-v-783f90ce="">` so the styling goes like:
```css
div header[data-v-783f90ce] {

}
```
When I believe in regular css is perfectly fine to use inheritance like:
```css
div[data-v-783f90ce] header {

}
```
Although I believe that the problem I witnessed has somewhat in common with the `data-v-` attribute but not quite sure is it the real reason for the current implementation behavior.
Nevertheless I think **vuejs** is great framework  and I just love it and especially the ease and convenience it creates and how good and logical it structured and interacts naturally. So I believe that the following precedent creates inconvenience and is in conflict with framework great nature.
I sure believe that what occurs isn't accidental so there's a particular reason for current implementation perhaps this is how upcoming native css specification looks like so you have to follow it or some other particular reason but still there might be a solution.

Probably `scoped="deep"`  where deep selecting works as default  or `scoped="inherit"` where `data-v` inheritance concerns parent and it takes care for its children styling might be a good tip so please consider it.

Thank you for your time keep up the good work. Appreciate it, great framework.

Issues.Title: Allow a single slot to be rendered for multiple times
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Currently if we render a slot for multiple times (eg. inside a `v-for` loop), we'll get

```
Duplicate presence of slot "${name}" found in the same render tree - this will likely cause render errors.
```

I know it's intentional to prevent render errors (like losing correct data binding) but consider the following use case: I have a `v-breadcrumbs` component which has a default item separator of a text node `/`, and I want to allows users to specify their own separators which can be anything, like an `<v-icon>` component.

Currently if I want to make it work, I have to define a scoped slot in the `v-breadcrumbs` component and bind nothing to it:

```html
<slot name="sep" v-bind="{}">/</slot>
```

And component users must define `slot-scope` on it and not use anything from it:

```html
<v-breadcrumbs>
  <v-icon slot="sep" slot-scope="_" name="angle-right"/>
</v-breadcrumbs>
```

And currently Vue is using slots as fallbacks for scoped slots with the same name. Whether the users can use a slot doesn't rely on if they want data from slot scope, but on whether the slot is gonna be rendered for multiple times inside the component self, this may raise more confusion for our users (like #8175).

So why don't we just get rid of such caveats and let a slot to be rendered more than once? We can clone them on duplication to prevent render errors as we already run the scoped slot function each time anyway. This makes the logic a lot simpler for users IMO: if we do not expect to use data from the slot scope, just use a slot, otherwise we'll always have to declare `slot-scope` to create the binding.

In addition, this would make documenting the (scoped) slots of a component more consistently, we just declare the data structure for a slot scope and users can decide if they want some data to bind to the `slot-scope` and don't need to care about how many times it will be rendered.


### What does the proposed API look like?
No additional API needed, just clone the slot nodes upon render and remove the waring about duplicated slots.

It may be implemented in userland today in a quite hacky way, see: https://codesandbox.io/s/lp11y2wovz

I just tweaked the `cloneVNode` function from the Vue core a little bit and it seemed to be working as expected using render function (without losing reactivity and event binding). There maybe some other edge situations I missed so correct me if it's not such trivial.

Issues.Title: Mute/Turn off <router-view> reactive rendering programatically
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Suppose an app like `Settings` app in iOS.

We navigate in a path like this: 
Settings -> General -> About This Phone

Then we can navigate in a reversed path by clicking 'back' button on the top left corner.

This "happy path" is easy to implement. But as a nature of web app, user may directly visit any "deep route" via a "deep url" and the "back" button loses its power to navigate through the reverse path:

1. User visits `https://app.example.com/settings/general/about`
2. User clicks back
3. App exits 
*Instead, we want the app to navigate to `/settings/general`*

I have managed to automatically inject the `/settings`, `/settings/general` routes when user directly visits `/settings/general/about`. The problem is these two pages and transitions associated to them show up in this process. 

I need the routing life cycles of auto injected routes, i.e. `/settings`, `/settings/general`,  to be complete to make the later `back` operation possible, but a complete routing life cycle causes the corresponding component to be rendered thus the problem occurred.

If I can mute/turn off the `<router-view>`'s rendering before the automatic injection starts and then turn it on later when the injection ends the problem would be hopefully solved.

### What does the proposed API look like?
```
router.mute()
router.unmute()
```

Issues.Title: History Mode Still Responds to #
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Currently, using 'history' mode relieves the app of being routed via an anchor tag. Great! However, when an anchor tag is appended to trigger an app behavior (e.g. www.my-vue-spa.com/playlist-1234#fullview), the router pushes this as part of the history so that the back-button undoes the anchor state instead of returning to the previous page.

### What does the proposed API look like?
The proposed solution would be to enforce what the current documentation currently suggests: to not let anchor tags drive routing history. The descriptions for 'hash' mode is "uses the URL hash for routing" and since history mode is not hash mode, the anchor tag would not affect $router.hash.

Issues.Title: High CPU usage in strict mode with a large state
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://jsbin.com/xetolobaba/edit?html,output](https://jsbin.com/xetolobaba/edit?html,output)

### Steps to reproduce
* Have a Vuex store with a large state (ex: thousands of reactive values)
* Activate strict mode
* Trigger any store mutation

### What is expected?
The mutation should complete in a few ms, like in non-strict mode.

### What is actually happening?
The mutation can take a very long time. It seems that vuex is iterating over the whole store at each `commit`.

---
Each store `commit` is really costly, even if they are all done at once (synchronously).

This is reproductible in any browser. For example, the example shows ~= 150ms in Chrome and ~= 250ms in Firefox.
This is reproductible in previous Vuex versions as well (2.3).

Related issues: https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/issues/1139 https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/issues/659
